name: Ben Vogt
comment info:
I noticed that vaccination rates increased significantly in more wealthy countries, but took a dip when it got to some of the very wealthiest countries like the United States. The size of a country’s population doesn’t seem to have any significant correlation with its number of vaccine doses per capita. It leaves me pretty curious about what could be the cause of that relationship, especially the part at the end where rates appear to be declining as wealth increases rather than increasing like they did for the majority of the graph. I’m also wondering what practices or characteristics of certain outliers like Chile resulted in so many more people getting vaccinated than in even the wealthier countries. Maybe there’s something they know that we don’t, and there’s something useful to be learned from that. I know a lot of people here in my community even that don’t, or didn’t want to get the vaccine, or the booster, even though our society has made it so convenient and easy to get them. Everyone has their personal reasons but I can’t help but wonder if there’s something about our society and our values that might be the reason such cases are so frequent. 

Why are Americans so averse to the vaccine?

name: Jonah
comment info:
I noticed that generally the weathlier a country you are, the more amount of doses per capita you’ve most likely administered. This can be affected by many different forces, such as infrastructure which could transport the vaccine, cost of maintaining the vaccine in freezers, advertising the vaccine, and even social effects such as anti-vax groups or just general concern by the public.

 How come there’s a sudden dip in the doses administered by capita in countries with more than ~$20k GDP? With their wealth, they should easily be able to distribute the vaccine and advertise the vaccine well into the community. Not to mention the probable widespread hospitals, clinics, and other organizations that are in these countries that can administer the vaccine.

In my community, there are a few amount of people who aren’t vaccinated, but more haven’t gotten the booster. Anti-Vax propaganda isn’t a huge problem in my community, but I’m sure it’s much more affluent in other states and even other countries that are modernized (my main hypothesis as to why super high GDP countries have a dip in doses administered by capita). With the current culture of my community, vaccines are seen as very important and necessary to beating this pandemic, so I’d be willing to guess that right now our doses per capita is much higher than national average.

Why aren’t the modernized super-rich countries leading the way in vaccine administration, as much as they should be?

name: Griffin
comment info:
I noticed The doses administrated per capita is positively correlated with the gross domestic product per capita. In short, the general trend the more money your country makes the more vaccines are going to be administered. I wonder why most of the very high GDP countries stay at a similar level of medium level GDP countries, since a linear correlation doesn’t seem to work for the high GDP. I also wonder why many of the high GDP countries seem to be clustered together, while countries like Brazil and South Africa are so far part in vaccinations, despite having similar GDPs. 
Also, the amount of people in a country loosely correlates with doses administered per capita, but only within similar GDP groups. For example, India, with the second most populous country in the world, administers more doses per capita compared to less populous countries like Kenya or Nigeria, even though they have similar GDPs. I wonder if this has to do with population density, since the doses being per capita would seemingly negate the population correlation argument.
I also wonder if this can be scaled down to certain regions of a country. For example, could this graph be done but with the fifty states? Would the trend be similar or different? Would reproducing similar scaled down versions in other countries (and maybe even smaller regions) produce the same results?

name: Moderator Sara

Thanks to all students who responded.  Here are some of the catchy headlines that we received: "Are Wealthier Countries Safer From COVID?" by Statistics at Forest Ridge School in Bellevue, Washington;  “Is Your Government’s Wealth the Reason You Aren't Vaccinated? by Iqra of North High School; “Does Wealth Equal More Vaccinations?” by Kendra of Georgia, “Vaccinations: The Next Inequality” by Camden, also from Georgia, “What Lies Behind Your Country's Vaccination Rate?” by Anna and "Dimes and Doses: The Relationship Between a Country's GDP and Vaccine Doses" by Sydney, both from Pennsylvania.

Some trends I notice within this graph is the general income/ GCP/wealth levels of the countries. The countries that have a higher average national income buy more vaccinations in general. replies.name: M
replies.comment info: Hi @Azlyn, You notice that “when countries overlap, their income equals greater income than they were as individual countries.” The different colors in the overlap do not represent any difference in income but rather are just an artifact of the overlap itself. This is a drawback of this type of plot. Because the points are centered at their actual values and are scaled by population, we cannot easily control what happens when they overlap. Suppose we wanted to remove the scaling by population to avoid this problem. How could we communicate that information instead? You also notice a relationship between wealth and vaccination rates. Does this relationship hold for every country. What other factors besides wealth could explain any deviations you see?
